reasoning: The critique targets a real component of the essay (Section 3.2’s case that unbounded linear views make mostly-great futures a narrow target because value-per-resource is highly uneven/fat-tailed), but that component is only one pillar among several (eutopian fragility in §2, bounded-view analysis in §3.3), so centrality is moderate. Substantively, the critique largely misfires: “law of diminishing marginal utility” is not a general refutation of the paper’s ‘linear in resources’ framework (which is about the moral value scaling with resources/space-time parcels, not consumer-utility for repeated units of a single good to the same agent), and diminishing returns can coexist with fat-tailed value-efficiency across different uses. The ‘winner-take-all’/“stable economy” framing reads as a strawman of the paper’s claim (about moral evaluation of futures) rather than an argument against it, lowering strength and correctness. Nonetheless the point that linear/unbounded modeling excludes some kinds of saturation/concavity is partially correct, and the critique is fairly clear and focused with little purely irrelevant filler.
title: Diminishing marginal utility undermines the case for winner-take-all resource allocation
